guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
Yes, this. The bible is full of different sources and some of them aren't even legitimate. Trying to resolve all the contradictions requires a twisting of interpretation completely beyond reason. And quoting the opinions of famous religious figures should in no way be on par with God, even though most people treat them as above him (especially with Paul and Peter).

You'll also notice how despite their commitment to written scripture, they conveniently ignore the parts they don't like. Pretty much anything can be argued from *somewhere* in the bible, so "it's in the bible" is not a valid argument. The overarching theme and its application to life is far more important.

And pointing this out always gets a bunch of Pharisees lining up to crucify you.

body: The Torah was written way before already the time of Jeremiah. A main part of a scribe's job was to interpret the scripture and teach it, to write explanations and prophesies that expounded on the Torah. So Jeremiah is condemning these teachers because of their false teaching, and that is clear by the context. The part of the passage you didn't highlight says the scribes had rejected the word of God. So it was there in its correct form for people like Jeremiah to read and verify. A similar situation is when Jesus condemns the Pharasees and scribes for misinterpreting scripture in Matt 23:23-24.

body:
> The Torah was written way before already the time of Jeremiah.

This is not true. Jeremiah was witnessing the priesthood forging fake books of law and specifically attacks a few of the things commanded in them, such as pagan animal sacrifices.

> A main part of a scribe's job was to interpret the scripture and teach it, to write explanations and prophesies that expounded on the Torah. So Jeremiah is condemning these teachers because of their false teaching, and that is clear by the context.

No, in his day, scribes were solely responsible for copying. Priests were the teachers. And notice how they *do not even have* the law, because of the false scribes.

> Matt 23:23-24

This basically teaches the opposite of much of the law in its current form. It's not *only* a misinterpretation, it's following the wrong parts instead of the correct ones.
body_html:
The Torah was written way before already the time of Jeremiah.

This is not true. Jeremiah was witnessing the priesthood forging fake books of law and specifically attacks a few of the things commanded in them, such as pagan animal sacrifices.

A main part of a scribe's job was to interpret the scripture and teach it, to write explanations and prophesies that expounded on the Torah. So Jeremiah is condemning these teachers because of their false teaching, and that is clear by the context.

No, in his day, scribes were solely responsible for copying. Priests were the teachers. And notice how they do not even have the law, because of the false scribes.

Matt 23:23-24

This basically teaches the opposite of much of the law in its current form. It's not only a misinterpretation, it's following the wrong parts instead of the correct ones.

body:
> Jeremiah was witnessing the priesthood forging fake books of law and specifically attacks a few of the things commanded in them, such as pagan animal sacrifices.

I will show you why my explanation is the only one that makes sense, by reading other passages of the Jeremiah.  

The Lord admonishes Israel for not following his law multiple times in the book of Jeremiah: 

Jeremiah 26:4: "Thus saith the LORD; If ye will not hearken to me, to walk in my law, *which I have set before you,*" 

Jeremiah 11:3 "And say thou unto them, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel; Cursed be the man that obeyeth not the words of this covenant"

Jeremiah 44:10: "They are not humbled even unto this day, neither have they feared, nor walked in *my law, nor in my statutes, that I set before you and before your fathers.*"

Here God says the people of Israel *have God's law*, but simply disobey it.  

In addition, at least a couple times in Jeremiah (e.g. Jeremiah 34:13-18, and 44:3) God is quoting specific laws in the Torah which Israel have disobeyed. Why would God admonish them if they didn't have an accurate saying of God's word? This is clearly in the context, that they aren't following God's word even though they have it, and that is why they face judgment according to what was written in the Torah. 

There are other multiple other points I can bring up (like how Daniel 100 years or so after Jeremiah was accurately quoting the book of Dueteronomy) to show how God has preserved the Bible over time. 

Thanks for prompting my study in this, this has strengthened my belief in the consistency of the Bible :).

parent.body:
> The Torah was written way before already the time of Jeremiah.

This is not true. Jeremiah was witnessing the priesthood forging fake books of law and specifically attacks a few of the things commanded in them, such as pagan animal sacrifices.

> A main part of a scribe's job was to interpret the scripture and teach it, to write explanations and prophesies that expounded on the Torah. So Jeremiah is condemning these teachers because of their false teaching, and that is clear by the context.

No, in his day, scribes were solely responsible for copying. Priests were the teachers. And notice how they *do not even have* the law, because of the false scribes.

> Matt 23:23-24

This basically teaches the opposite of much of the law in its current form. It's not *only* a misinterpretation, it's following the wrong parts instead of the correct ones.

body:
You quote extensively from the later chapters, which figures, as it is generally agreed that only chapters 1-25 are authentic to Jeremiah, and even those were edited during the redactions. It's a miracle that 8:8 survived at all, and the condemnation of animal sacrifice and other laws (there may have been more of them which did not survive the redaction). You'll also notice how the part about not burning people at the end of chapter 7 is repeated two other times much later, and these change it to being about sacrifices to Baal, but the only context in the original is that it makes the place "The Valley of Slaughter"; this could be a reference to the fake commandments to burn people at the stake. Does this mean the later portions have no use at all? That there is no truth in them? No, but it should be taken with a grain of salt. Even the authentic parts should not be considered absolute truth, because of the mistakes and deliberate editing.

And as for your quote in chapter 11: context please. God is *re-giving* them the covenant in this chapter because their ancestors had corrupted it. And it is "Listen to my voice," the same thing referenced after condemning sacrifice rituals in chapter 8.

Does this mean the later portions have no use at all? That there is no truth in them? No, but it should be taken with a grain of salt. Even the authentic parts should not be considered absolute truth, because of the mistakes and deliberate editing.

And as for your quote in chapter 11: context please. God is re-giving them the covenant in this chapter because their ancestors had corrupted it. And it is "Listen to my voice," the same thing referenced after condemning sacrifice rituals in chapter 8.

body:
So do you propose to just ignore the Bible because it was written later and corrupted? You wouldn't know anything at all about Christianity if it didn't survive to this day. I am quite sure that God is powerful enough to watch over the ages and make sure that the words in Bible are true and correct. How else would then be possible for people to even know Him? Besides, the punishment for altering the Bible is stated in there, and I believe, that in case someone tampered or tried to tamper with the scripture, God intervened, so the right words were persevered until today.

Also I believe, that people who ''never got the chance''actually got the chance. I believe God is just and gives everyone who ever lived on this planet at least one chance in their life where they experience something which can lead them to surrendering their lives to Him.

> So do you propose to just ignore the Bible because it was written later and corrupted?

No, but I accept that when something contradicts the rest or randomly interrupts the middle of a passage, it's probably not original. And I also realize that letters written by disciples are not on the same authority as Jesus is, they are just typical preaching. It's an overall message, not letter by letter accuracy, especially not through translation.

Deny it all you want, but there are thousands of variants, plenty of them having theological implications. And the further back you go, the more variants would've existed. Our earliest full texts only date from the 300s btw, plenty of time for the Catholic church to take over and destroy any deviant copies, which we can already prove happened with multiple known versions, such as Marcion, the gospel of the Hebrews, etc. Even with that, there are several different text types that still exist today. And even within the non-varying text, there are tons of internal contradictions from different authors with different ideas, and scribal additions. You cannot claim that every letter is accurate.

> I am quite sure that God is powerful enough to watch over the ages and make sure that the words in Bible are true and correct.

He is, but you're assuming he sanctioned the bible when he didn't. It didn't even exist until 382 AD! Before that were individual scriptures coming in multiple different versions, most of which were disputed. In fact, he says the opposite in Jeremiah 8:8, warning of such tampering.

> How else would then be possible for people to even know Him?

He still had a plan. Fortunately, scribes added more material than they omitted. So with the help of the holy spirit you can discern truth from lie. It may be a test, whether we will follow vain idols and traditions of men with excuses like "it's in the bible!" or him.

> Besides, the punishment for altering the Bible is stated in there,

Implying it's possible to do so...

> You wouldn't know anything at all about Christianity if it didn't survive to this day.

> I believe God is just and gives everyone who ever lived on this planet at least one chance in their life where they experience something which can lead them to surrendering their lives to Him.

You have contradicted yourself. First you say it's impossible without Christianity and the bible, then you say it is. I agree with the latter.

And even within the non-varying text, there are tons of internal contradictions from different authors with different ideas, and scribal additions. You cannot claim that every letter is accurate.

I am quite sure that God is powerful enough to watch over the ages and make sure that the words in Bible are true and correct.

He is, but you're assuming he sanctioned the bible when he didn't. It didn't even exist until 382 AD! Before that were individual scriptures coming in multiple different versions, most of which were disputed. In fact, he says the opposite in Jeremiah 8:8, warning of such tampering.

How else would then be possible for people to even know Him?

He still had a plan. Fortunately, scribes added more material than they omitted. So with the help of the holy spirit you can discern truth from lie. It may be a test, whether we will follow vain idols and traditions of men with excuses like "it's in the bible!" or him.

Besides, the punishment for altering the Bible is stated in there,

Implying it's possible to do so...

You wouldn't know anything at all about Christianity if it didn't survive to this day.

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
So do you propose to just ignore the Bible because it was written later and corrupted? You wouldn't know anything at all about Christianity if it didn't survive to this day. I am quite sure that God is powerful enough to watch over the ages and make sure that the words in Bible are true and correct. How else would then be possible for people to even know Him? Besides, the punishment for altering the Bible is stated in there, and I believe, that in case someone tampered or tried to tamper with the scripture, God intervened, so the right words were persevered until today.

Also I believe, that people who ''never got the chance''actually got the chance. I believe God is just and gives everyone who ever lived on this planet at least one chance in their life where they experience something which can lead them to surrendering their lives to Him.
